text: Alcohol by volume (often shortened to ABV) tells how much ethanol there is in an alcoholic drink. The quantity is measured at a temperature of . Common levels of alcohol are 3-5 percent for cider, 4-7 percent for beer, and 12-14 percent for wine. Distilled alcoholic drinks ( called spirits) contain more than twenty percent ethanol. A directive of the European Union of 1976 says that the alcohol content of alcoholic drinks must be measured using the ABV measurement described above. ==Other ways of measuring alcohol content== Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac (1777-1850) and Johann Georg Tralles (1763-1822) developed other means of measuring alcohol content. These units are usually measured in degrees, noted 째GL, or 째GT. The scale Gay-Lussac developed is almost equal to the ABV scale described above.
